physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Echocardiography showed good biventricular contractility and normal-sized atria. Catheterization showed a very minimal leak in the apex of the newly created wide interventricular septum, low right ventricle pressure, and a mild pulmonary stenosis. Right and left ventricular outflow were unobstructed.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: At the end of the fifth postoperative year, the patient developed exertion-related dyspnea, and echocardiography showed progression of the tricuspid valve incompetence, a pulmonary stenosis producing right ventricle pressure of 65 mm Hg, and 2 small hemodynamically insignificant ventricular septal defects.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Postoperative evaluation revealed a wide opening of the pulmonary valve that could not have produced a hemodynamically significant stenosis, with no significant findings in the previous ventricular septal defects.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: The anatomy showed a well-integrated septation patch with ring dilatation and anterior leaflet prolapse of the right-sided atrioventricular valve. The left atrioventricular valve had thickened leaflets but was otherwise competent.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Computed cardiac tomography revealed an adequately placed and fixed septation patch, equal growth of the 2 ventricles to normal sizes, and absence of previously described ventricular septal defects without any other morphologic or anatomic cardiac abnormalities.
